items.title: White House says using US military is ‘always an option’ for acquiring Greenland
items.standfirst: European leaders push back forcefully against US president’s desire to seek takeover of Arctic territoryDonald Trump and his advisers are looking into “a range of options” in an effort to acquire Greenland, noting in a White House statement on Tuesday that using the US military to do so is “always an option”.“President Trump has made it well known that acquiring Greenland is a national security priority of the United States, and it’s vital to deter our adversaries in the Arctic region. The president and his team are discussing a range of options to pursue this important foreign policy goal, and of course, utilizing the US military is always an option at the commander-in-chief’s disposal,” White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement. Continue reading...
items.content: European leaders push back forcefully against US president’s desire to seek takeover of Arctic territoryDonald Trump and his advisers are looking into “a range of options” in an effort to acquire Greenland, noting in a White House statement on Tuesday that using the US military to do so is “always an option”.“President Trump has made it well known that acquiring Greenland is a national security priority of the United States, and it’s vital to deter our adversaries in the Arctic region. The president and his team are discussing a range of options to pursue this important foreign policy goal, and of course, utilizing the US military is always an option at the commander-in-chief’s disposal,” White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement. Continue reading...

items.title: US military ‘always an option’ to secure Greenland, says Donald Trump
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump is exploring ways for the United States to take control of Greenland, with military force “always an option", the White House said on Tuesday, raising tensions with NATO ally Denmark.
items.content: President Donald Trump is exploring ways for the United States to take control of Greenland, with military force “always an option", the White House said on Tuesday, raising tensions with NATO ally Denmark.

items.title: We'll defend Greenland, European leaders vow - as US suggests it could take military action
items.standfirst: Using the military to take Greenland is "always an option" the White House says, amid mounting tension over Donald Trump's plans for the territory.
items.content: Using the military to take Greenland is "always an option" the White House says, amid mounting tension over Donald Trump's plans for the territory.

items.title: Trump considering military options to acquire Greenland
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump is exploring how to take control of Greenland and using the US military is "always an option," the White House said Tuesday, further upping tensions with NATO ally Denmark. Washington's stark warning came despite Greenland and Denmark both calling for a speedy meeting with the United States to clear up "misunderstandings." FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson reports from Washington.
items.content: President Donald Trump is exploring how to take control of Greenland and using the US military is "always an option," the White House said Tuesday, further upping tensions with NATO ally Denmark. Washington's stark warning came despite Greenland and Denmark both calling for a speedy meeting with the United States to clear up "misunderstandings." FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson reports from Washington.

items.title: Why is Donald Trump renewing calls for takeover of Greenland?
items.standfirst: US refuses to rule out military force to take control. This is why an attack on Nato ally would end alliance. And what do Greenlanders think?Soon after Donald Trump’s removal of Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, last weekend, he quickly moved on to the subject of Greenland, renewing calls for a US takeover of the Arctic territory.The US president said on Sunday that he needed Greenland “very badly”, prompting a ramping up of tensions between the US, Greenland and Denmark. Continue reading...
items.content: US refuses to rule out military force to take control. This is why an attack on Nato ally would end alliance. And what do Greenlanders think?Soon after Donald Trump’s removal of Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, last weekend, he quickly moved on to the subject of Greenland, renewing calls for a US takeover of the Arctic territory.The US president said on Sunday that he needed Greenland “very badly”, prompting a ramping up of tensions between the US, Greenland and Denmark. items.title: Live: Trump announces plan to refine, sell up to 50 million barrels of Venezuelan oil
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Tuesday unveiled a plan to refine and sell up to 50 million barrels of Venezuelan oil that had been stuck ⁠in Venezuela under US blockade, in a further sign that Washington is coordinating with the Venezuelan government since capturing President Nicolas Maduro. Read our blog to see how the day's events unfolded.
items.content: President Donald Trump on Tuesday unveiled a plan to refine and sell up to 50 million barrels of Venezuelan oil that had been stuck ⁠in Venezuela under US blockade, in a further sign that Washington is coordinating with the Venezuelan government since capturing President Nicolas Maduro. Read our blog to see how the day's events unfolded.

items.content: President Trump has publicly dismissed the Nobel winner Machado saying she doesn't have local support and respect.

items.title: Full interview: María Corina Machado on Maduro and Venezuela
items.standfirst: María Corina Machado spoke with "CBS Evening News" anchor Tony Dokoupil on Tuesday, January 6, about the U.S. capture of Venezuela's Nicolás Maduro, her opposition movement that she says is ready to lead the country, Venezuelan Interim President Delcy Rodriguez and more.
items.content: María Corina Machado spoke with "CBS Evening News" anchor Tony Dokoupil on Tuesday, January 6, about the U.S. capture of Venezuela's Nicolás Maduro, her opposition movement that she says is ready to lead the country, Venezuelan Interim President Delcy Rodriguez and more.

items.title: Machado says Venezuelans are "very grateful" to Trump for ousting Maduro
items.standfirst: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado hailed President Trump for removing Nicolás Maduro from power in a network exclusive interview with CBS News — and made the case for why her political coalition should lead the country.
items.content: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado hailed President Trump for removing Nicolás Maduro from power in a network exclusive interview with CBS News — and made the case for why her political coalition should lead the country.

items.title: Machado says her coalition should lead Venezuela: "We are ready and willing"
items.standfirst: María Corina Machado told CBS News in a network exclusive interview the people of Venezuela have picked her opposition movement to lead the country in the wake of Nicolás Maduro's ouster.
items.content: María Corina Machado told CBS News in a network exclusive interview the people of Venezuela have picked her opposition movement to lead the country in the wake of Nicolás Maduro's ouster.

items.title: Three women are shaping Venezuela's political future after Marduro's capture
items.standfirst: Three women, Delcy Rodriguez, Cilia Flores and Marína Corina Machado, are shaping Venezuela's future after a U.S. military operation included the capture of deposed president Nicolás Maduro. NBC News' Yasmin Vossoughian has more on the impact of these women and where they stand today.
items.content: Three women, Delcy Rodriguez, Cilia Flores and Marína Corina Machado, are shaping Venezuela's future after a U.S. military operation included the capture of deposed president Nicolás Maduro. NBC News' Yasmin Vossoughian has more on the impact of these women and where they stand today.

items.title: White House doubles down on Trump's Greenland pursuit, says military action "always an option"
items.standfirst: The White House is doubling down on President Trump's pursuit of Greenland, saying that "using the U.S. military is always an option." The renewed focus on the Danish territory comes as questions remain about Trump's strategy in Venezuela. Ed O'Keefe and Lilia Luciano have more. Then, CBS Evening News anchor Tony Dokoupil sits down for an exclusive interview with Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado.
items.content: The White House is doubling down on President Trump's pursuit of Greenland, saying that "using the U.S. military is always an option." The renewed focus on the Danish territory comes as questions remain about Trump's strategy in Venezuela. Ed O'Keefe and Lilia Luciano have more. Then, CBS Evening News anchor Tony Dokoupil sits down for an exclusive interview with Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado.

items.title: Yemen's separatist leader al-Zubaidi flees ahead of talks, Saudi-led coalition says
items.standfirst: The leader ​of Yemen's separatist Southern Transitional Council (STC), Aidarous al-Zubaidi, fled to an unknown destination on Wednesday, after skipping an airplane flight to Riyadh for talks to tackle a crisis that caused a major feud between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
items.content: The leader ​of Yemen's separatist Southern Transitional Council (STC), Aidarous al-Zubaidi, fled to an unknown destination on Wednesday, after skipping an airplane flight to Riyadh for talks to tackle a crisis that caused a major feud between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

items.title: Trump administration halts more than $10bn for childcare and family assistance
items.standfirst: Democrats condemn move in California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York, calling it ‘vindictive’ and ‘cruel’Donald Trump’s administration is freezing more than $10bn in federal childcare and family assistance funds to California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) said, citing what it called concerns about fraud and misuse.“For too long, Democrat-led states and Governors have been complicit in allowing massive amounts of fraud to occur under their watch,” Andrew Nixon, HHS spokesperson, said in a statement. Continue reading...

items.content: Baidu Inc.’s artificial-intelligence chip unit has hired banks for an initial public offering in Hong Kong that may raise as much as $2 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

items.title: Chat Platform Discord Files Confidentially for IPO
items.standfirst: Discord Inc. filed confidentially for an initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter, adding to a rapidly growing pipeline of venture capital-backed tech listings.
items.content: Discord Inc. filed confidentially for an initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter, adding to a rapidly growing pipeline of venture capital-backed tech listings.

clusters.title: CIA turncoat who sold out to Soviet Russia dies in prison
clusters.neutral_headline: Aldrich Ames, CIA agent who spied for Soviet Union and Russia, dies aged 84

items.title: CIA turncoat who sold out to Soviet Russia dies in prison
items.standfirst: A CIA turncoat who orchestrated one of the most damaging intelligence breaches in American history by selling secrets to the Soviet Union and Russia has died in prison.
items.content: A CIA turncoat who orchestrated one of the most damaging intelligence breaches in American history by selling secrets to the Soviet Union and Russia has died in prison.

items.title: Aldrich Ames, CIA agent who spied for Soviet Union and Russia, dies aged 84
items.standfirst: In damaging intelligence breach, Ames admitted to passing information to Moscow for nearly a decadeAldrich Ames, the CIA agent who spied for the Soviet Union and Russia in one of the most damaging intelligence breaches in US history, has died in a Maryland prison. He was 84.His death on Monday was confirmed by the Bureau of Prisons.Ames is best known as an ex-CIA agent who spied on the US on behalf of the Soviet Union. Ames, along with his wife, Rosario Ames, was arrested in February 1994 and pleaded guilty without a trial to espionage and tax evasion. Aldrich was charged with espionage, and his wife with aiding and abetting his activities. Continue reading...
items.content: In damaging intelligence breach, Ames admitted to passing information to Moscow for nearly a decadeAldrich Ames, the CIA agent who spied for the Soviet Union and Russia in one of the most damaging intelligence breaches in US history, has died in a Maryland prison. He was 84.His death on Monday was confirmed by the Bureau of Prisons.Ames is best known as an ex-CIA agent who spied on the US on behalf of the Soviet Union. Ames, along with his wife, Rosario Ames, was arrested in February 1994 and pleaded guilty without a trial to espionage and tax evasion. Aldrich was charged with espionage, and his wife with aiding and abetting his activities. Continue reading...

clusters.title: New Zealand Court Acts to Stop Spread of Hacked Medical Records
clusters.neutral_headline: New Zealand Court Acts to Stop Spread of Hacked Medical Records

items.title: New Zealand Court Acts to Stop Spread of Hacked Medical Records
New Zealand Court Acts to Stop Spread of Hacked Medical Records
items.standfirst: The New Zealand High Court has issued an urgent injunction barring the publication of stolen medical data after hackers accessed about 430,000 private patient documents held on a health portal used by more than a third of the country’s population.
items.content: The New Zealand High Court has issued an urgent injunction barring the publication of stolen medical data after hackers accessed about 430,000 private patient documents held on a health portal used by more than a third of the country’s population.

clusters.title: Iran security forces clash with protesters as death toll rises to at least 36
clusters.neutral_headline: Iranian security forces clash with protesters at Tehran’s grand bazaar

items.title: Iran security forces clash with protesters as death toll rises to at least 36
items.standfirst: Protesters in Iran defied authorities Tuesday, hitting the streets in the capital, Tehran, and smaller cities to chant anti-government slogans amid an ongoing violent crackdown that one human rights group says has left at least 36 dead
items.content: Protesters in Iran defied authorities Tuesday, hitting the streets in the capital, Tehran, and smaller cities to chant anti-government slogans amid an ongoing violent crackdown that one human rights group says has left at least 36 dead

items.title: Iranian security forces clash with protesters at Tehran’s grand bazaar
items.standfirst: Nationwide protests continue to grow as rights groups accuse authorities of cracking down on demonstratorsIranian security forces have clashed with protesters staging a sit-in at Tehran’s grand bazaar, firing teargas and expelling demonstrators as the nationwide protest movement continued to grow in its 10th day.The violence on Tuesday at a location that carries historical symbolism as an activist hub during the country’s 1979 revolution comes as rights groups accuse authorities of cracking down on protesters. Continue reading...
items.content: Nationwide protests continue to grow as rights groups accuse authorities of cracking down on demonstratorsIranian security forces have clashed with protesters staging a sit-in at Tehran’s grand bazaar, firing teargas and expelling demonstrators as the nationwide protest movement continued to grow in its 10th day.The violence on Tuesday at a location that carries historical symbolism as an activist hub during the country’s 1979 revolution comes as rights groups accuse authorities of cracking down on protesters. Continue reading...

items.title: Iran to try risky economic concessions as it attempts to quell protesters’ anger
items.standfirst: President wants to placate demonstrators calling for political change, action on corruption and help with cost of livingThe Iranian government is attempting risky economic concessions as it tries to meet the escalating demands of protesters seeking fundamental political change, a clampdown on corruption and an easing of the squeeze on living standards of the poor.Now entering their ninth day, the protests have spread to 27 of Iran’s 31 provinces, with a human rights group claiming that the death toll has passed 35 with more than 1,200 arrested. Continue reading...
items.content: President wants to placate demonstrators calling for political change, action on corruption and help with cost of livingThe Iranian government is attempting risky economic concessions as it tries to meet the escalating demands of protesters seeking fundamental political change, a clampdown on corruption and an easing of the squeeze on living standards of the poor.Now entering their ninth day, the protests have spread to 27 of Iran’s 31 provinces, with a human rights group claiming that the death toll has passed 35 with more than 1,200 arrested. Continue reading...

items.title: Three children dead in Iran protests as security forces accused of ‘indiscriminate targeting’
items.standfirst: Escalating protests sparked by economic chaos have seen at least 20 people killed and nearly 1,000 arrested, say human rights groupsAt least three children are reported to have been killed and more than 40 minors arrested after eight days of the ongoing protests across Iran, as human rights groups accuse the regime’s security forces of “indiscriminate targeting of civilians”.The nationwide uprising sparked by the collapse of the country’s currency and rising living costs has spread to at least 78 cities and 222 locations, with demonstrators calling for the end of the regime, according to the US-based Human Rights Activists in Iran (HRAI). Continue reading...
items.content: Escalating protests sparked by economic chaos have seen at least 20 people killed and nearly 1,000 arrested, say human rights groupsAt least three children are reported to have been killed and more than 40 minors arrested after eight days of the ongoing protests across Iran, as human rights groups accuse the regime’s security forces of “indiscriminate targeting of civilians”.The nationwide uprising sparked by the collapse of the country’s currency and rising living costs has spread to at least 78 cities and 222 locations, with demonstrators calling for the end of the regime, according to the US-based Human Rights Activists in Iran (HRAI). Continue reading...

items.title: Swiss ski bar not inspected for five years before deadly fire, mayor says
items.standfirst: The New Year's Eve fire at a bar in Crans-Montana killed 40 people and injured 116.
items.content: The New Year's Eve fire at a bar in Crans-Montana killed 40 people and injured 116.

items.title: Sparkler candles banned by Swiss mayor after New Year's bar fire killed 40
items.standfirst: The Swiss bar that caught fire during a New Year's celebration and killed 40 people had not been inspected since 2019, officials have said.
items.content: The Swiss bar that caught fire during a New Year's celebration and killed 40 people had not been inspected since 2019, officials have said.
